line=3233 tag=M+CN:  (1) Floating Quantifier (FQ) Construction: host noun-CASE ... ClP/MP
line=3234 tag=L+DB:      a. MP: Mizu-ga kinoo               3-littoru koboreta b. ClP: Hako-ga kinoo            3-ko otita
line=3235 tag=G+DB:               water-NOM yesterday 3-liter          spilled         box-NOM yesterday 3-CL fell
line=3236 tag=T+DB:              `3 liters of water spilled yesterday'                 `3 boxes fell yesterday'

language: Japanese (jpn)
line=3237 tag=M+CN:  (2) Non-Floating (non-FQ) Quantifier Construction:     [ host noun + ClP/MP ]-CASE
line=3238 tag=L+DB:      a. MP: [Mizu 3-littoru]-ga kinoo           koboreta b. ClP: [Hako 3-ko]-ga kinoo         otita
line=3239 tag=G+DB+CR:                                    yesterday spilled                 [box 3-CL]-NOM yesterday fell
line=3240 tag=G+DB+CR:             [water 3-liter]-NOM

doc_id=1716 igt_id=igt1716-3 133 138 M+AC+LN+CN B M+CN L G T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=133 tag=M+AC+LN+CN:  JAPANESE ADVERSITY PASSIVE (some of the data taken from Kubo 1992)
line=134 tag=B:
line=135 tag=M+CN:  (15)      Direct passive
line=136 tag=L:          a. Taroo-ga          Ziroo-o        hihansita.
line=137 tag=G:               Taro-Nom        Jiro-Acc       criticized

line=204 tag=G+DB:  within a given language, using only examples with anaphor binding. More-                      J.-and M.-ACC            each other-NOM        saw
line=205 tag=T+DB:  over, the binding restrictions that arise in scrambling also arise under move-                (lit.) `Each other saw John and Mary.'

doc_id=2136 igt_id=igt2136-22 744 747 L+SY G T+SY T+SY+AL
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=744 tag=L+SY:  a) Johnwai [S' [S Marygak   zibunzisinok/*i hihansita] [C to]] itta
line=745 tag=G:     John         Mary        zibunzisin     criticized that said

line=1054 tag=M:           b.        [TP NPi [vP ti [VP [PartP [vP PRO i [VP ... V] v ] te] V] v ] T]

line=1056 tag=M:                                  P
line=1057 tag=B:
line=1058 tag=M:           d.        [TP NPi [vP ti [VP NPj [ModP [vP PRO j [VP ... V] v ] yooni] V] v ] T]
line=1059 tag=B:
line=1060 tag=B:
line=1061 tag=M:  3.5 The status of yooni and tense/aspect morphemes
line=1062 tag=M:  Before discussing the theoretical implicat ions of (41), it is important to consider the
line=1063 tag=M:  status of yooni and its complement. This is because the control embedded clause in
line=1064 tag=M:  (41d) appears to retain the possibility of a T position in the embedded clause, due to
line=1065 tag=M:  the apparent 'non- past' form of the embedded verb. However, the interaction
line=1066 tag=M:  between the status of yooni and the real status of the embedded verb prevents us
line=1067 tag=M:  from assuming a T in the embedded control clause.
line=1068 tag=M:           First, consider the status of yooni. I follow Uchibori (1996), who claims
line=1069 tag=B:
line=1070 tag=B:
line=1071 tag=G:           John -Nom why Mary-Acc praise-IntMd Comp tried                      Q
line=1072 tag=T:           'Why did John try that pro would praise Mary t.'

doc_id=2446 igt_id=igt2446-76 1080 1082 L+SY G T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=1080 tag=L+SY:  (iv)     John1 -ga Mary 2 -ni [Bill3 -ga    zibunzisin 1 /3 -o home -ro      to] meijita.
line=1081 tag=G:           John -Nom Mary-Dat Bill-Nom oneself-Acc praise-ImpMd Comp ordered
line=1082 tag=T:           'John ordered Mary that Bill should praise him/herself.'

doc_id=2446 igt_id=igt2446-77 1083 1085 L G T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=1083 tag=L:  (v )     * John-ga [Mary -ga     Bill-o home -yoo          to]   kokoromita.
line=1084 tag=G:           John -Nom Mary-Nom Bill-Acc praise-IntMd Comp tried
line=1085 tag=T:           'John tried that Mary would praise Bill.'

doc_id=2446 igt_id=igt2446-78 1107 1109 L G T+AC

doc_id=2446 igt_id=igt2446-91 1697 1714 L+SY G L+SY G B B M M M M M B B B B B B T+LT
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=1697 tag=L+SY:          c.       John- ga         Mary- ni [VP sono ringo- o     taberu- yooni] itta node
line=1698 tag=G:                   John-Nom Mary-Dat               that apple-Acc eat - to            told so that
line=1699 tag=L+SY:                   Bill- mo [VP soo suru yooni] itta.
line=1700 tag=G:                   Bill-also     so do to        told
line=1701 tag=B:
line=1702 tag=B:  34
line=1703 tag=M:     Wurmbrand (1998: 72) treats verbs selecting a yooni complement as non -restructuring infinitive
line=1704 tag=M:  verbs, since she assumes that the embedded verb is marked for tense. For Wurmbrand, it would
line=1705 tag=M:  make no difference as she wants no functional material here. However, as discussed in Section 3.5,
line=1706 tag=M:  the marker is assumed not as a tense marker, but as an aspect marker. Let us assume so here in this
line=1707 tag=M:  section.
line=1708 tag=B:
line=1709 tag=B:
line=1710 tag=B:
line=1711 tag=B:
line=1712 tag=B:                                                 38
line=1713 tag=B:
line=1714 tag=T+LT:                   (Lit.)'John told Mary to eat that apple and Bill told her to do so, too.'

line=532 tag=L:  Taroo wa sake o noma-nai ka tabako o suwa-nai-ka

line=539 tag=B:
line=540 tag=T:  `It is not the case that Taro drinks and smokes
line=541 tag=B:
line=542 tag=T:  it is not the case that Taro drinks, or it is not the case that Taro smokes.

doc_id=2832 igt_id=igt2832-1 106 116 M+LN+DB+EX L+DB L+DB L M G+DB M G G+DB B T+DB+LT
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=106 tag=M+LN+DB+EX:  (10) Japanese: The local preposition ni takes a region noun.
line=107 tag=L+DB:       Hon wa teeburu              no     ue            ni    aru.                                        `the pupil sits at a desk.'
line=108 tag=L+DB:                                          shita                                                           x e {SIT(x) & LOC(x, AT desk)}(e)
line=109 tag=L:                     tosho-kan            naka
line=110 tag=M:                                                                                                    Only the lowest argument can be incorporated into the verb. With ditransitive verbs, it is
line=111 tag=G+DB:       book TOP table              GEN on-region        LOC be
line=112 tag=M:                                                                                                    always the recipient (construed as goal) which gets incorporated.
line=113 tag=G:                                          under-region
line=114 tag=G+DB:                     library              in-region                                                 (17) a. ´m´k                     p'-o"la-k'im-d.
line=115 tag=B:                                                                                                                       karandas
line=116 tag=T+DB+LT:       lit. `The book is located in the on-region of the table.' etc.                                       mother pencil            REFL-child-give-INDIC

doc_id=29 igt_id=igt29-34 914 927 M+AC+LN L B M M M M M B M B B G T

line=914 tag=M+AC+LN:      (31) Japanese (Nishiyama 1996: 12)
line=915 tag=L:           a. John-wa Bill-o osi-taosi-ta                 koto-wa osi-taosi-ta            kedo
line=916 tag=B:
line=917 tag=M:  7
line=918 tag=M:    In Hale and Keyser (1993: 76) the D-structure and S-structure of an unergative verb contain a true external
line=919 tag=M:  argument, appearing in the Spec position of the functional projection of IP. Following this, we can say that
line=920 tag=M:  John is the external argument of V1 at D-structure, whereas it is the internal argument of V2 and it moves to
line=921 tag=M:  the Spec position of IP at S-structure.

doc_id=3165 igt_id=igt3165-3 166 172 M+LN+CN B L G L G T+AC

line=166 tag=M+LN+CN:  Sluicing constructions in Japanese
line=167 tag=B:
line=168 tag=L:  (19)   Mary-ga nanika-o           katta rasii ga,
line=169 tag=G:         Mary-NOM something-ACC bought seems but
line=170 tag=L:         boku-wa [nani-o ka] wakaranai.
line=171 tag=G:         I-TOP      what-ACC Q not-know
line=172 tag=T+AC:         'It seems that Mary has bought something, but I don't know what.'     (Takahashi 1994)

line=177 tag=T+AC:         'Mary wsa fired. I want to know why.' (Takahashi 1994)

line=207 tag=T+AC:         'I don't know what (it is).' (Takahashi 1994)

line=14280 tag=T+CR:              `Customs let the trader only

doc_id=3191 igt_id=igt3191-236 14281 14302 L G L G B M M M M M M M M M M M M B B M B T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=14281 tag=L:           b. Zeikan wa gyoosya ni                Huransu kara wain dake yunyuu o
line=14282 tag=G:              customs TOP trader DAT              France from wine only import ACC
line=14283 tag=L:              mitome-ta.
line=14284 tag=G:              permit-PAST
line=14285 tag=B:
line=14286 tag=M:      6
line=14287 tag=M:        Space limitations preclude me from giving a detailed examination of Matsumoto's (1996) anal-
line=14288 tag=M:  ysis. For a fuller discussion, see Kubota (2005).
line=14289 tag=M:      7
line=14290 tag=M:        Matsumoto (1996) actually claims that `adjunct transfer' is possible in LVC. For an extensive
line=14291 tag=M:  discussion on the nonevidencehood of the apparent cases of adjunct transfer brought up by Mat-
line=14292 tag=M:  sumoto (1996), see Yokota (1999) and Kubota (2005).
line=14293 tag=M:      8
line=14294 tag=M:        Strictly speaking, NPs with focus particles are not (canonical) quantifiers. However, they behave
line=14295 tag=M:  like quantifiers in that they are scope-taking elements, which is the only crucial property relevant
line=14296 tag=M:  to the discussion here. I use these items throughout this paper because the relevant distinction in
line=14297 tag=M:  meaning is clearer than cases involving more `canonical' quantifiers.
line=14298 tag=B:
line=14299 tag=B:
line=14300 tag=M:                                                  236
line=14301 tag=B:
line=14302 tag=T:              `The only thing customs let the trader import from France was wine.'

line=14323 tag=L:   (5)    Taroo   wa       Hanako    ni damatte terebi o    mi-sase-ta.
line=14324 tag=G:          Taro    TOP      Hanako    DAT silently TV ACC watch-cause-PAST
line=14325 tag=T:          `Taro   made      Hanako   silently watch the TV'
line=14326 tag=T+AL:          `Taro   silent   ly made   Hanako watch the TV.'

doc_id=3199 igt_id=igt3199-2 13 15 L G M+AC+EX
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=13 tag=L:         b. [Taro to Jiro]i-ga ei tataki-aw-ta.
line=14 tag=G:            Taro and Jiro-NOM hit-AW-past
line=15 tag=M+AC+EX:         Three types of the V-aw construction (Tonoike 1991)

doc_id=3199 igt_id=igt3199-3 17 21 M+EX M+EX L G T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=17 tag=M+EX:         a. The direct reciprocal V-aw construction
line=18 tag=M+EX:            There is a gap (e) in an argument position of the verb V.
line=19 tag=L:            [Taro to Jiro]i-ga ei tataki-aw-ta.
line=20 tag=G:            Taro and Jiro-NOM hit-AW-past
line=21 tag=T:            "[Taro and Jiro]i hit each otheri."

doc_id=3199 igt_id=igt3199-4 22 26 M+EX M+EX L G T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=22 tag=M+EX:         b. The indirect reciprocal V-aw construction
line=23 tag=M+EX:            There is a gap (e) in a possessor position of an argument NP.
line=24 tag=L:            [Taro to Jiro]i-ga [ei hahaoya]j-o home-aw-ta.
line=25 tag=G:            Taro and Jiro-NOM mother-ACC praise-AW-past
line=26 tag=T:            "[Taro and Jiro]i praised [each otheri's mothers]j.

doc_id=3199 igt_id=igt3199-5 27 30 M+EX L G T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=27 tag=M+EX:         c. The competitive V-aw construction: There is no gap.
line=28 tag=L:            [Taro to Jiro]-ga yorokobi-aw-ta.
line=29 tag=G:            Taro and Jiro-NOM be-pleased-AW-past
line=30 tag=T:            "Taro and Jiro showed the joy together."

doc_id=3199 igt_id=igt3199-6 34 38 M+AC M+EX L+SY G T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=34 tag=M+AC:  (3)    Nishigauchi's (1992) analysis (cf. Heim, Lasnik and May (1991))
line=35 tag=M+EX:         Aw = the distributor, e = the trace of the reciprocator (syntactically active)
line=36 tag=L+SY:         [IP [John to Mary]i-ga [IP ti [VP1 ti [VP1 Opj [VP2 ti [V'2 tj aisi]] aw]] te-iru]]
line=37 tag=G:              John and Mary-NOM                                        love-AW-prog
line=38 tag=T:         "[John and Mary]i love each otheri."

line=405 tag=L+DB:  (36) a. ??keikan-ga          dorobooi-o [mise-kara i detekuru                                           The ergative NP is in the embedded clause, where its case is
line=406 tag=M+DB:                                                                                                   o
line=407 tag=G+DB:             policeman-NOM thief-ACC store-from EC come.out                                               determined by the transitive verb `explode'
line=408 tag=L+DB:          tokoro]-o       taihosita                                                                       No selectional restrictions
line=409 tag=M+DB:                                                                                                   o
line=410 tag=G+DB:          tokoro-ACC arrested
line=411 tag=T+DB:          `The policeman caught the thief when he was coming out of the
line=412 tag=T+DB+EX:            store.' (Forward Object Control, restricted because of the Double-o       6.4 Alternation between Forward and Backward Control/Raising
line=413 tag=C+DB:            Constraint operating in Japanese)

language: Japanese (jpn)
line=414 tag=L+DB:       b. keikan-ga          i      [mise-kara dorobooi-ga detekuru                   If a language has both options for one and the same verb, what are interpretive
line=415 tag=G+DB:          policeman-NOM EC store-from thief-NOM come.out                              differences between the forward and backward configurations?
line=416 tag=L+DB:          tokoro]-o       taihosita                                                   What determines the choice of one construction over the other?
line=417 tag=G+DB:          tokoro-ACC arrested
line=418 tag=T+DB:          `The policeman caught him when a/the thief was coming out of the               "When the grammar permits both backward and forward pronominalization
line=419 tag=T+CN+DB:            store.' (Backward Object Control)                                            use the backward option only if you have a reason to do so." (Reinhart 1976)

doc_id=3475 igt_id=igt3475-19 247 249 M+AC+LN L G
language: Japanese (jpn)

doc_id=3683 igt_id=igt3683-119 8510 8531 L M M M M M M M M M M M M M M M B B M B G T
language: Japanese (jpn)
line=8510 tag=L:  31.     Calvin-ga         Hobbes-ni piza-o           kaeshita
line=8511 tag=M:  104 "Second" here is not meant in a sequential sense; because of the restrictions on movement, accusative in
line=8512 tag=M:  overt object shift examples will be checked first in the syntax. The MCP is to be interpreted as a
line=8513 tag=M:  morphological well-formedness condition against which a completed derivation is checked; if the wrong
line=8514 tag=M:  cases have been assigned when all features have been checked at LF, the derivation will crash. If the right
line=8515 tag=M:  cases have been assigned and the MCP is satisfied, the derivation is good (with respect to the MCP).
line=8516 tag=M:  Alternatively, assuming a "Late Insertion" approach to case morphology (Halle and Marantz (1993)),
line=8517 tag=M:  particular structural cases might have nothing to do with the syntax at all - as long as an NP has its case
line=8518 tag=M:  feature checked in an AgrP, the correct morphology will be inserted prior to Spell-Out according to the
line=8519 tag=M:  parameter in 30) above. On either view, it is a morphological dependency that determines what cases appear
line=8520 tag=M:  on an NP, rather than syntactic heads.
line=8521 tag=M:            Masa Koizumi (p.c.) points out that it is possible to maintain cyclic, bottom-up case-checking if
line=8522 tag=M:  "stacking" of morphological cases is allowed; on such an account two cases (nominative, then accusative)
line=8523 tag=M:  could be assigned to an ECM object and only the outer one realized, giving the correct accusative
line=8524 tag=M:  morphology. See Kuroda (1992) for a similar proposal; I leave the merits and problems of such a proposal
line=8525 tag=M:  to future research.
line=8526 tag=B:
line=8527 tag=B:
line=8528 tag=M:                                                      163
line=8529 tag=B:
line=8530 tag=G:             Calvin-N       Hobbes/D      pizza-A            return-Pst
line=8531 tag=T:             "Calvin returned pizza to Hobbes"

line=1117 tag=B:
line=1118 tag=B:
line=1119 tag=M:  15
line=1120 tag=M:    One possible adjustment is to go back to Vallduvi's original claim that sentences can
line=1121 tag=M:  lack links. In (40) or (41), A's second utterance is an all-focus sentence. Such a stance
line=1122 tag=M:  would, however, significantly weaken the validity of the current account for the
line=1123 tag=M:  disambiguation of the Japanese existential since the obligatoriness of a link is tied to the
line=1124 tag=M:  loss of the part-whole interpretation in the NP-ga^NP-ni order in root contexts.
line=1125 tag=B:
line=1126 tag=M:                                               23
line=1127 tag=B:

line=5622 tag=G:               John or Bill-NOM what-ACC drank             Q

line=8121 tag=M+CN:  (i)    Wh-island effects
line=8122 tag=B:

doc_id=94 igt_id=igt94-122 8131 8137 M+CN B L B G B T

line=8131 tag=M+CN:  (ii)    Paying the wh-island tax

line=8133 tag=L:           John-wa [Mary-ga        nani -o katta ka dooka] dare -ni tazuneta no?
line=8134 tag=B:

line=8136 tag=B:
line=8137 tag=T:          `Who did John ask whether Mary bought what?'
